What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning

Comments_List: I think i gained a good survey of molecular cell biology, but the homework did not reinforce these concepts in my point of view.
I developed skills in thinking critically about papers and experiments. This class challenged me to not only think about the methods used in a critical way.
This course provided the overview of cell biology. I was able to learn what cell processes occur more in depth.
I learned Cell Bio.
The course gives us a systematic overview about cell biology and is very well-organized. It expanded my general knowledge in cell biology.
I solidified my knowledge in the area of cell biology, especially on the workings of the various organelles. It was very helpful!
It brought everyone up to the same level. There were little details and recent developments in the field that were new.

I felt as though I received a well-rounded review of cell biology. Before I took the course I wasn't sure where I stood in terms of knowledge and expertise but now I feel more oriented within the field.
Although I am not interested in Cell Biology as a research pathway, I must say this course is very well organized and taught a some interesting insights about cell biology.

Having taken no Cell Biology classes in before I thought this was a nice primer for several fundamental topics in CB. I learned some techniques I had not known before and recent research progress in these topics.

I'm not sure I learned any completely new topics, but what we covered in class was comprehensive and very in-depth. The papers were interesting and helped me learn more about techniques used in cell biology studies.
I learned so much about cell biology that I had never learned in undergrad. This course was game changing in increasing my knowledge of how cells function alone and in systems.

Reading and analyzing primary papers
Getting to know research in MCDB department
Students don't really have to learn the material, and although the homework helps to make students think about experimental methods and how to apply them, i don't think its conceptually very deep.
The homework assignments usually helped cement what we had learned in the class. However, the lack of feedback kept us from further understanding the concept.
This class was truly excellent, and a joy to take. I think its only weakness was that it was in the early afternoon, so sometimes I fell asleep even though the material was fascinating.

The discussion part of the course is the most helpful for me. I just have one simple suggestion for it. It would be great if we can receive feedback from the teachers or TAs about our synopsis. I actually take it very seriously and regard it as a good opportunity to improve my writing. Or we can create an anonymous site that posts the synopsis from the students so that people can know about other people's ideas and discuss about them.

The course was able to teach those who had not learned about some of the topics. 

The lecturers selected had a range of ability to lecture. While this is expected, the long drawn out lectures is an issue for engagement. Reading from text heavy slides is less than desirable, but so is going through more material than can be fit in the lecture time. Being conscious of the time span that is provided for each lecturer, as well as what is really relevant for application for a future career. Some material was included that would be considered too detailed for one who needs broad knowledge for general understanding. These lectures that went into to extraneous detail about techniques or specific papers became less engaging and often lost the thread of the topic.

Strengths:
Good professors and for the most part the homework assignments were straight forward and had clearly defined objectives. 

Weaknesses: 
Not sure why there was a need for so many lectures on cell signaling and the cytoskeleton. Other just as important topics did not receive the same level of detail and would've been nice.

1.The organization of the course, in particular small discussion sections are excellent (this is much better organized than Genetics 625) 
2. The grading scheme is fantastic and professors provide feedback.
3. The course could be improved by making sure all of lecturers engage students, and try to be dynamic and active. From my experience when lecturers were engaging and interactive with students that's when I learned the most. Even though, the topics might be completely off my research interests. 
 However, there were two lecturers which their classes were the most boring  and monotone lectures I had to sit through. As a result, my grades suffered because their material was terribly boring and useless. Please discuss this with all of lecturers to make sure their teaching style improves.

Strengths - Good faculty and good choice of topics. I did like the paper discussions. I actually thought some more of the discussions might be interesting for dissecting papers.

Weaknesses - There was some overlap and redundancy I felt with some of the topics -- perhaps could be placed closer together in time (Cell Fate and Stem Cell lectures?). I thought the Cytoskeleton was a little too long and could have been compacted, and maybe in turn add one or two more discussion sections?

Strengths: overall very good lecturers, and the structure of the course made a lot of sense

Weaknesses: Not much participation in class, although paper discussions were good
He individual instructors were very well selected and knew their topic in depth. You could feel that most of them enjoyed teaching about what they study and that made the course fun.

STRENGTHS
- Weekly short answer questions and professor feedback were really helpful for engaging with content
- Lecture powerpoints were posted regularly and promptly

WEAKNESSES
- Journal clubs were sometimes poorly organized (sometimes did not get through all figures)
Yes, I would recommend this course. This course does well in laying the groundwork for graduate students pursuing studies in this field.
Absolutely. It was a fascinating, well-taught course.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to those who are interested in cell biology!
Definitely.
Yes - good informative course.
If their research interests align with cell biology or they think this could benefit them in the future, then yes.
Depends on their background in CBio - could see this being largely redundant for those with stronger CBio backgrounds.
Yup!
Yes!
Yes! Laid back but engaging - freedom to engage more deeply with material that I find interesting/relevant. Provides both breadth and depth into cell bio
